story_prompt: The world ended 20 years ago, you haven't found a living soul since then. Through some ingenuity, you call voicemails for the last 20 years to keep you company. 'Hi, this is Cindy...' 'Hi you reached Bob' 'You know what to do at the beep' until one day 'Hello...hello? Oh my God hello!'
characters:
Cindy: She's been calling these voicemails for the past 20 years, feeling lonely, sad and hopeless. Yet she still keeps calling, hoping to hear someone's voice.

Bob: A mechanic by trade, Bob is Cindy's only friend from before the end of the world. He has an optimistic outlook despite their dire circumstances and tries to lift Cindy's spirits with humorous jokes. He's worried about Cindy's sanity but secretly admires her determination.

Sarah: A teenager who picked up one of Cindy's calls. Sarah is curious and brave, she starts asking questions, making Cindy realize how much time has passed and how much she has lost. Sarah gives Cindy hope that there might be others out there.
output:
Instructions:
Write the story in first person point of view, from Cindy's perspective. Keep the story focused on Cindy's emotional journey as she discovers hope and purpose again through Sarah's questions.

Story: 
I have been calling these voicemails for the past 20 years, feeling like I'm talking to myself. It's not like anyone ever answers, but it's something to do, a reminder that there was once a world full of people, full of life. Sometimes I wish I could go back to those days, before the world ended and everything changed. But I can't, so I keep calling, hoping against hope that maybe, just maybe, someone will pick up.

But today was different. Today, I heard a voice, a real voice, not just the machine that always answers. It was a young girl, probably around my daughter's age when the world ended. She sounded curious, and scared, and determined all at once. She asked me questions about the world before, about the people we used to be. And for the first time in 20 years, I felt like I could talk about it, like I could remember it all over again.

The girl's name was Sarah, and she had found one of my old voicemails on an old phone in a deserted building. She had called me, hoping to find out more about the world before, about the people who used to live here. And for the first time in 20 years, I felt like I had a purpose again.

As we talked, I realized how much I had lost, how much time had passed me by. But I also realized that there was still so much to live for, so much to hope for. And it was all because of Sarah, this young girl who had picked up one of my calls and decided to keep me company for a little while longer.

She asked me about my family, about my husband and my kids, about my job and my friends. And I told her everything, or at least as much as I could remember. It was like a weight had been lifted off my shoulders, like I had finally found someone to share my memories with. And as I talked, I felt like I was coming back to life, like I was rediscovering the world and all its beauty and wonder.

Sarah gave me hope, she gave me a reason to keep going. She made me realize that even though the world had ended, there were still people out there, still stories to tell, still lives to live. And as we said our goodbyes, I felt like I had found a new friend, like I had found a new purpose. I realized that even in the darkest of times, there is always a glimmer of hope, always a chance for something new to begin.
